Republika Srpska (RS): Restrictions on movement for those over 65 with the following exception:  1) persons over 65 and over on Tuesdays and Fridays from 7.00 to 10.00, for the purpose of purchasing basic foodstuffs, medicines and doing business in banks, with compliance with duties and recommendations as follows:  - shop owners, pharmacies and bank management are obliged to strictly adhere to established protection measures relating to disinfection, social distance and stay in the room of up to three people, - recommended for shop owners, pharmacies and the management of banks to provide services exclusively to those persons in the specified period, - it is recommended to persons younger than 65 years of age not to make purchases and not to perform operations in banks in the period referred to in item 3 of this conclusion,  2) persons up to 75 years of age in rural areas, and for the purpose of performing agricultural work, with mandatory compliance with the protective measure of social distance and  3) beekeepers, regardless of age, who have a decision on registration of apiaries issued by the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and water management, on Tuesdays and weekends, from the place of residence to the apiary, except in the period from 20.00 to 05.00. Banking Agencies have announced a six-month loan repayment moratorium for restructuring credit  arrangements for individuals and legal entities which are found to have aggravated circumstances  for loans repayments due to COVID-19. Banking Agencies have instructed banks to track clients  and exposure portfolios affected by COVID-19.  ? Banks are also instructed to consider additional customer relief, including reviewing current fees  for services and avoiding charging fees to handle exposure modifications. All banks were ordered  not to pay dividends or bonuses.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Bosnia-and-Herzegovina.pdf

Support to private sector activity and employment: Businesses in FBiH are entitled to  subsidies in the amount of BAM 245 (~EUR 120) per month, per employee. The obligation  to make advanced payments on corporate income tax for businesses and self-employers  is abolished. Lease amounts are decreased by 50% for business premises managed by  the FBiH Office of Joint Affairs. Corporate income tax liabilities in RS are postponed until  30 June. All borrowers from the Investment and Development Bank of RS are granted  three month repayment moratorium. Deadlines for filing tax returns and salary  specifications have been extended to 30 April 2020 in both entities. https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Bosnia-and-Herzegovina.pdf

Sarajevo Canton Crisis HQ has issued orders and measures as follows (in force from July 6th to July 20th):  The elderly and persons suffering from chronic diseases should limit movement and the use of public transportation. Retirement homes and centres for care of persons with special needs are ordered to ban visitation.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200829154713/http://www.ohr.int/report-on-measures-and-orders-adopted-during-the-pandemic-of-covid-19-in-bih/

21 July, first article mentioning access to testing outside of priority groups. Persons suspected of being infected with the new corona virus are being tested at the Clinical Center in Banja Luka, and in Bijeljina and Foca. When it comes to commercial PCR tests that are done for travel abroad, the tests are done at the Institute of Public Health of the RS in cooperation with our regional centers where swabs are taken and then submitted to the institute for testing.   As of today, commercial PCR testing can be done in the Department of Microbiology of the Clinical Center of the University of Tuzla, where a commercial PCR test costs about 110 euros (215 convertible reels) + VAT, as well as at the Department of Microbiological Diagnostics of Zenica Cantonal Hospital at 110 euros (215 convertible). reel).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210816204536/https://www.akta.ba/vijesti/kako-uraditi-komercijalno-pcr-testiranje-u-bih-/120963    US and UK embassy websites do not mention access to testing.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200730123453/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The order is obligatory to wear protective masks indoors with respect to a distance of at least 1 meter, as well as in open space, if it is not possible to maintain a physical distance of 2 meters between people in the open. Due to the aggravated epidemic situation of COVID-19, the new order "allows the gathering of people in a certain area under the following conditions: no more than 50 people indoors and no more than 100 people in the open."  http://web.archive.org/web/20200730123944/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/209/krizni-stab-stozer-fmz-okupljanja-ogranicena-na-50-ljudi-u-zatvorenom-i-100-na-otvorenom-prostoru-rad-ugostiteljskih-objekata-ne-duze-od-23-sata      It is unclear if there is a policy change in Republika Srpska, the other entity comprising BiH.

FBiH crisis HQ, new measures and recommendations in force as of July 25th: elderly citizens to avoid getting out as much as possible; Extended ban on visitations to penitentiary institutions, nursing homes, other social care institutions.  Similar policies are not found in Republika Srpska.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200829154713/http://www.ohr.int/report-on-measures-and-orders-adopted-during-the-pandemic-of-covid-19-in-bih/

With the abolishment of the State of Emergency, business entities are open and working hours returned to normal, However, wearing masks and physical distancing (a minimum of 2 metres) are mandatory in all indoor public places.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200818233248/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Bosnia-and-Herzegovina.pdf

Starting July 16, BiH borders are open for citizens and residents of EU and Schengen countries with a negative PCR test not older than 48 hours (this does not apply to Croatian citizens).  For other non-resident foreign nationals, there is still an entry ban, though some with special circumstances (e.g. For a business meeting, to a funeral, for medical treatment, or in the company of a BiH-citizen spouse) may enter. Special documentation and/or a negative COVID test may be required.  Linkhttps://web.archive.org/web/20200808104752/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Private clinics around the country perform PCR (~230km) and serological (~40km) COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test. Results are quick (usually within 24 hours).  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) will test people with symptoms—regardless of nationality—free of charge. (They do not test asymptomatic people or provide test verification for travel purposes!) To arrange a test, contact your canton’s health center for additional guidance.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200829101240/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

US Citizens and British Nationals, including those with residence in Bosnia and Herzegovina, need a negative COVID-19 (PCR) test result that is not older than 48 hours. Some groups are exempt from this rule, including: diplomats accredited to and resident in Bosnia and Herzegovina, EUFOR/NATO staff, freight drivers and crew, and foreigners in transit to their country of residence. Changes to restrictions may be introduced at short notice. You should comply with any screening measures put in place by the authorities. You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. No change in policy.  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) will test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. They do not test asymptomatic individuals or provide test verification for travel purposes. To arrange a test, contact your canton’s health center for additional guidance. Private clinics around the country perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for serological. Results are quick (usually within 24 hours).  https://web.archive.org/web/20201218063400/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina:  Night clubs and discos will remain closed until further notice. Restaurants are allowed to remain open until 11 p.m. All services must take additional hygiene measures and continuously disinfect them. From 5.11.2020, all legal persons, i.e. companies, in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina are obliged to set flexible working hours in the work processes they perform and, where possible, to introduce teleworking.     Republika Srpska  All legal entities, i.e. companies, and public administration are invited to organise the work as a teleworking wherever possible. Opening hours for catering establishments are from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m., with live music prohibited. A minimum of 10 m2 of space must be available for each table with a maximum of 4 people. The opening hours of gambling operators (casinos, vending machines and similar ones) must be reduced to 10 p.m. The so-called "drugstores" (small grocery stores), which are usually open 24H, are only allowed to sell counters after 10 p.m. All shops and businesses must take additional hygiene measures and continuously disinfect them.    Brko District  From 7.12.2020, opening hours of catering establishments, fitness centres, gambling operators, sports schools are limited to 7 p.m.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina:   Public gatherings of more than 30 people outdoors and indoors are prohibited. Parliament's sittings are excluded from this. Exceptionally, no more than 70 people may be present in theatres and cinemas. Organizers are obliged to register all planned events with the cantonal Ministry of Health. Competition activities for sports clubs and athletes may only take place without an audience.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html    Republika Srpska:   All public gatherings with more than 50 people are prohibited.  All private gatherings (weddings, baptisms and birthday parties, family meetings, etc.) with more than 10 people are prohibited.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html    Brcko District: On 3 November, public gatherings in closed spaces were banned.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102174538/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/bosniaandherzegovina/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.2+Physical+distancing&Type=Section    (22 Nov) religious gatherings (funerals, holidays) as well as weddings limited to 30 persons.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200829154713/http://www.ohr.int/report-on-measures-and-orders-adopted-during-the-pandemic-of-covid-19-in-bih/

I believe previous coders misinterpret it as of "public gathering"  Various entities in Bosnia and Herzegovina issued separate policies.  Republika Srpska: On 21 October, some of the existing measures were reinforced and expanded (forbidden public gatherings in groups of more than 50 people, private and family gatherings in groups of more than 10 people, live music in hospitality facilities)  Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina: Large gatherings are prohibited (on a similar scale), but I did not find policies specific to "private gatherings".  Brcko District: All public gatherings and unofficial gatherings over 20 people were banned (since 20 July). On 3 November, public gatherings in closed spaces were banned, while the wearing of masks was made mandatory in open spaces for people in groups of two or more.   Sarajevo Canton: limits to the number of people gathering (maximum 60 people in open and 30 in closed spaces) since 15 Oct.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102160920/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/bosniaandherzegovina/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.2+Physical+distancing&Type=Section

Public transportation resumed working under specified protection measures for operators and passengers since 11 May (RS) and 12 May (FBIH). Since 30 May, inter-city transportation (all trains and buses) resumed in FBIH. There have been no quarantined buildings or residential areas.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102160920/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/bosniaandherzegovina/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.2+Physical+distancing&Type=Section    Brko District: From 7.12.2020, public transport for passenger transport is limited from 5 a.m. to 7 p.m.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

Since 11/11/2020, an exit lock is in place from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina,   Since 22/11/2020, an exit lock is in place in the Brcko district from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m.  No specific stay-at-home policy in Republika Srpska and Canton of Sarajevo.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

Banking Agencies have announced a six-month loan repayment moratorium for restructuring credit arrangements for individuals and legal entities which are found to have aggravated circumstances for loans repayments due to COVID-19. Banking Agencies have instructed banks to track clients and exposure portfolios affected by COVID-19. Banks are also instructed to consider additional customer relief, including reviewing current fees for services and avoiding charging fees to handle exposure modifications. All banks were ordered not to pay dividends or bonuses.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109060549/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

FBiH: In supermarkets and drugstores, only one person per 10 m2 of space is allowed. Regardless of the size of the area, shopping centers must not have more than 400 people at any time. All existing cash registers must be constantly occupied. Companies are required to engage surveillance personnel to supervise the number of people within the facility, as well as when entering and leaving the facility. Restaurants may offer food and drinks outdoors (summer garden, terrace) as well as indoors, whereby the seating tables must be visibly marked.     RS:All companies, entrepreneurs and natural persons who provide services to citizens in direct contact must provide the masks to citizens who do not have them, as well as monitor compliance with the measures with security guards.  Restaurants and gambling organizers can keep open from 06.00-24.00.  All shops and shopping centers must monitor compliance with the measures with security guards, especially with regard to the number of visitors.  The so-called "drugstores" (small grocery stores, which are usually open 24h) are allowed to carry out between 00:00 and 06.00 o'clock only counter sales  http://web.archive.org/web/20210711174501/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

RS: All public gatherings with more than 120 people are prohibited.  FBiH:Public gatherings of more than 100 people outdoors and more than 50 people indoors are prohibited. A distance of 2 m must be observed. Parliamentary sittings are excluded from this. Exceptionally, a maximum of 100 people may be present in theatres and cinemas, at congresses, conferences and other educational events. It is also possible to organise larger gatherings (up to a maximum of 150 people indoors and up to 300 people outdoors) under specially defined conditions, i.e. all participants need either an antigen or PCR test, not older than 48 hours, or a certificate of their recovery, not older than six months, or a certificate of fully carried out vaccination. All epidemiological measures must be complied with. Organisers are obliged to register all planned events with the cantonal ministry of health.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210711174501/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

FBiH: The federal crisis unit has called on citizens to avoid public and private gatherings and restrictions on movement. Public gatherings of more than 100 people outdoors and more than 50 people indoors are prohibited.  RS: All private gatherings (weddings, baptismal and birthday parties, family gatherings, etc.) with over 70 people are prohibited.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210711174501/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

Since 11.6.2021, the '3 G' rule applies to the entry of foreigners:    Presentation of a negative PCR test or a rapid antigen test for SARS-CoV-2, which must not be older than 48 hours on arrival within Europe or 72 hours on arrival from outside Europe from the time of smear acceptance to arrival at the border crossing  Presentation of a medical certificate of recovery, valid from 14 to 180 days after illness  Presentation of a certificate of fully carried out vaccination before more than 14 days before entry    http://web.archive.org/web/20210711174501/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

FBiH: Masks are mandatory with a physical distance of 2 m in closed public premises. Children under the age of 6, disabled persons, athletes and persons who practice sporting leisure activities in sports halls are exempt from the obligation to wear masks. Outdoors, masks are only mandatory if the distance cannot be maintained (marketplaces, stops and similar).  RS: Masks are mandatory in closed rooms, as well as a personal distance of 2 m. Children under the age of 7, disabled persons and persons who practice sporting leisure activities in sports halls are exempt from the obligation to wear masks. If the distance can not be maintained, masks are also recommended outdoors.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210711174501/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

A,B,C  Since 12.2.2021 vaccinations have been taking place in the entity Republika Srpska and since 10.3.2021 in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Through the COVAX system, as well as donations from various countries and direct purchases, about 650,000 vaccination units have been delivered to Bosnia and Herzegovina so far. The entity Republika Srpska also procures Russian and Chinese vaccines directly. Entity Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina was able to conclude a contract with the Chinese Synopharm for the procurement of 500,000 vaccination units in mid-June 2021. Delivery details are not yet known.  Which vaccines are available in BiH? Flight schedules are reduced from normal, and subject to change. Foreign nationals are permitted to enter the country provided they possess documentation showing they have been fully vaccinated against COVID-19, recovered from COVID-19, or that they have tested negative using a PCR test; the test must have been taken within 48 hours before arrival if coming from somewhere in Europe, or 72 hours if arriving from a country, not in Europe. Cabin crews, freight crews, diplomats, members of foreign militaries stationed in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and passengers transiting the country are not required to provide a negative test. Citizens of Croatia, Serbia, and Montenegro and their immediate family members can enter without a negative COVID-19 test, provided they are entering from their country of citizenship.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210726163236/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/497546/bosnia-and-herzegovina-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-july-2-update-29    https://web.archive.org/web/20210726162737/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Although everything is slowly returning to normal, many companies and institutions have still organized work partly from home, depending on the conditions.    All companies in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina were recommended to set flexible working hours in the work processes they carry out and, where possible, to introduce teleworking.    All companies that employ more than 20 people are requested to issue a contingency plan immediately. This is intended to harmonize the organization of the work of these companies with the recommendations and guidelines given by the Institute for Public Health of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the cantonal institutes for public health.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211001161054/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

Till 07 Oct 2021:  Public gatherings of more than 100 people in the open air and of more than 50 people in closed rooms are prohibited. A distance of 2 m must be kept. This does not apply to parliamentary sessions. Exceptionally, a maximum of 100 people may be present in theaters and cinemas, at congresses, conferences and other educational events. It is also possible to organize larger gatherings (max. 150 people indoors and max. 300 people outdoors) under specially defined conditions, ie all participants need either an antigen or PCR test, not older than 48 hours , or a certificate of their recovery, not older than six months, or a certificate of a complete vaccination. All epidemiological measures must be observed. Organizers are obliged to notify the cantonal health ministries of all planned events.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211001161054/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

ince June 11th, 2021, the 3-G rule applies to the entry of foreigners:     Submission of a negative PCR test or a rapid antigen test for SARS-CoV-2, which must not be older than 48 hours for arrival within Europe or 72 hours for arrival from outside Europe, calculated from the time of the swab to arrival at the border crossing  Submission of a medical certificate of recovery, valid from 14 to 180 days after illness  Submission of a certificate of a complete vaccination more than 14 days prior to entry     https://web.archive.org/web/20211001161054/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

There are different debt/contract relief measures in place as of 01 Oct-2021.    Moratorium or postponement of loan repayments until June 30, 2021  Introduction of a grace period for the repayment of the capital portion of the loan obligations for loans until December 31, 2021.  Extension of the deadline for repayment of annuities  Extending the duration of one-off loans, including revolving loans and overdrafts until December 31, 2021  Approval of additional loans to overcome the current liquidity difficulties;  other measures taken by the bank to facilitate loan repayments by customers and to establish a sustainable customer business     Micro, small and medium-sized enterprises receive bank guarantees from guarantee funds forThe purpose of securing loans from commercial banks in the amount of up to 50% of the loan(for micro-businesses up to a maximum of BAM 250,000 or around EUR 125,000, for small businessesup to a maximum of BAM 1,000,000 or around EUR 500,000, for medium-sized companies up to a maximum of BAM3,000,000 or around EUR 1.5 million per application).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211001170901/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/bih-foerdermassnahmen-firmen-unternehmer-covid-19.pdf

Seems to be generally available.   Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for antigen.  Turnaround of results and availability of testing appointments vary based on the city yet clinics in most large cities have testing options daily and return results within 24 hours.  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. To arrange a test, contact your canton’s health center for additional guidance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211001161050/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

It is compulsory to wear a mask with a physical distance of 2 m in closed public areas. Children under 6 years of age, disabled people, athletes and people who practice sporting leisure activities in sports halls are exempt from wearing a mask. In the open air, masks are only compulsory if the distance cannot be kept (marketplaces, bus stops, etc.).   https://web.archive.org/web/20211001161054/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html
